content.title: Aggregate Supply
content.definition: Aggregate supply (AS) represents the total quantity of goods and services that all firms in an economy are willing and able to produce at each price level during a given time period. The aggregate supply curve shows the relationship between the overall price level and total real GDP produced, distinguishing between short-run aggregate supply (SRAS) which is upward-sloping due to sticky wages and prices, and long-run aggregate supply (LRAS) which is vertical at potential output where all prices have fully adjusted.

definitions_glossary.aggregate_supply: The total quantity of real GDP that firms plan to produce at each price level - the economy-wide supply relationship
definitions_glossary.short_run_aggregate_supply: AS curve where some input prices (especially wages) are sticky - upward-sloping because firms increase output when product prices rise faster than costs
definitions_glossary.long_run_aggregate_supply: AS curve when all prices (including wages) have fully adjusted - vertical at potential GDP, determined by real factors (labor, capital, technology)
definitions_glossary.potential_output: The level of real GDP produced when all resources are fully employed at sustainable rates - also called full-employment GDP or natural rate of output
definitions_glossary.sticky_wages: Wages that adjust slowly to changing economic conditions due to contracts, fairness concerns, or information lags - key reason SRAS slopes upward
definitions_glossary.sticky_prices: Product prices that adjust slowly due to menu costs, contracts, or coordination failures - contributes to SRAS slope
definitions_glossary.supply_shock: An event that shifts the SRAS curve by changing production costs - positive shocks shift SRAS right, negative shocks shift left
definitions_glossary.price_level: A measure of overall prices in the economy - typically measured by GDP deflator or consumer price index
definitions_glossary.natural_rate_of_output: The level of output produced when unemployment equals its natural rate - where LRAS intersects horizontal axis
definitions_glossary.misperceptions_theory: Lucas's explanation of upward-sloping SRAS: firms confuse general price increases with relative price increases for their products
definitions_glossary.sticky_wage_theory: Explanation of SRAS: nominal wages set in advance don't immediately adjust to unexpected price changes, affecting real wages and employment
definitions_glossary.menu_costs: The costs of changing posted prices - includes physical costs, customer relations, and decision-making costs
definitions_glossary.capacity_utilization: The percentage of potential output actually being produced - affects SRAS through diminishing returns at high utilization

key_points: Short-run AS slopes upward: Higher price levels increase output because some costs (especially wages) are sticky and adjust slowly
Long-run AS is vertical at potential output: All prices eventually adjust, so only real factors (technology, labor, capital) determine output
Three theories explain SRAS slope: (1) Sticky wages, (2) Sticky prices (menu costs), (3) Misperceptions about relative prices
SRAS shifts from supply shocks: Negative shocks (oil price spike) shift SRAS left causing stagflation; positive shocks shift right
LRAS shifts from changes in productive capacity: More labor, capital, technology, or productivity shift LRAS right (economic growth)
Short-run equilibrium: Where AD intersects SRAS - can be above or below potential output
Long-run equilibrium: Where AD intersects both SRAS and LRAS - economy at potential output with stable expectations
Adjustment process: If Y > Y*, upward pressure on wages shifts SRAS left until Y = Y*; if Y < Y*, downward wage pressure shifts SRAS right
Phillips curve relationship: SRAS implies inverse short-run relationship between inflation and unemployment
Policy implications: Monetary/fiscal policy can affect output in short run (moving along SRAS) but only prices in long run

examples.title: 1973-74 Oil Crisis - Negative Supply Shock
examples.description: OPEC oil embargo quadrupled oil prices from $3 to $12/barrel. This massive negative supply shock shifted SRAS left significantly. Result: stagflation - simultaneous high inflation (12.3% in 1974) and recession (GDP fell 0.5% in 1974). Output fell from Y* to below while price level rose. Traditional demand-side policies couldn't fix both problems: stimulating demand raises inflation more; contracting demand worsens recession.
examples.context: Classic example of SRAS shift causing stagflation - policy dilemma
examples.data: US 1974: Real GDP growth -0.5%, Inflation 12.3%, Unemployment rose from 4.9% to 8.5% (BLS, BEA data)

examples.title: 1990s Productivity Boom - Positive Supply Shock
examples.description: Information technology revolution increased labor productivity growth from 1.4% (1973-95) to 2.5% (1995-2000). This positive supply shock shifted both SRAS and LRAS right. Result: Economy could grow faster without inflation - 'Goldilocks economy.' Real GDP grew 4%+ annually while inflation fell below 3% and unemployment reached 4%. Challenged conventional estimates of NAIRU.
examples.context: Positive supply shock enabling non-inflationary growth
examples.data: US 1995-2000: Real GDP growth 4.3%/year, Core inflation 2.1%, Unemployment 4.0% (Jorgenson & Stiroh, 2000)

examples.title: 2020 COVID-19 Pandemic - Dual Supply and Demand Shock
examples.description: Pandemic caused both SRAS shift left (factory closures, supply chain disruptions, worker illness) and AD shift left (lockdowns, fear reducing spending). Initially deflationary as demand fell faster. By 2021-22, demand recovered (stimulus) but supply constraints persisted (chip shortages, labor shortages). SRAS left-shifted relative to recovering AD → inflation surge to 9.1% (June 2022).
examples.context: Complex interaction of supply and demand shocks
examples.data: US: Q2 2020 GDP -31.2% annualized. 2022: Core PCE inflation 5.2%, labor force participation still below pre-COVID (Fed data)

examples.title: Japan's Lost Decades - Long-Run Supply Decline
examples.description: Japan's potential output growth slowed dramatically due to aging population (shrinking labor force), declining investment, and stagnant productivity. LRAS growth fell from 4%+ (1980s) to under 1% (2000s-2010s). Combined with persistent weak AD creating deflationary expectations. Illustrates how demographic changes affect LRAS over time, not just short-run fluctuations.
examples.data: Japan potential GDP growth: 4.4% (1980s), 1.8% (1990s), 0.7% (2000s) per OECD estimates

examples.title: US 1981-82 Volcker Disinflation - Movement Along SRAS
examples.description: Fed raised federal funds rate to 20% to combat 13% inflation. This contractionary monetary policy shifted AD left sharply. Economy moved down along the SRAS curve: output fell (recession, 10.8% unemployment in 1982) as price level increase slowed (disinflation). Over time, lower inflation expectations shifted SRAS right as wage demands moderated. By 1983, inflation fell to 3% and recovery began.
examples.context: Movement along SRAS vs shift of SRAS as expectations adjust
examples.data: US 1982: Unemployment 10.8%, Inflation fell from 13% (1980) to 3% (1983), Real GDP fell 1.8% in 1982

content.statement: Aggregate supply represents the total output that all firms in an economy are willing to produce at each price level. Understanding the distinction between short-run (upward-sloping) and long-run (vertical) aggregate supply is essential for analyzing macroeconomic fluctuations, supply shocks, inflation, and the effectiveness of stabilization policies.

explanation.intuition: Think of aggregate supply as the economy's production capacity and willingness to produce. In the short run, when overall prices rise but wages and other costs haven't caught up yet, firms find it profitable to produce more - their revenues rise faster than costs. This is why SRAS slopes upward. But in the long run, workers demand higher wages and all costs adjust to the higher price level, eliminating the extra profit. So long-run output depends only on real capacity - how many workers, machines, and how good the technology - not on the price level. The economy's potential output is like a speed limit: you can temporarily exceed it (overheating) or fall short (recession), but you always tend back toward it.
explanation.key_insight: The crucial distinction between SRAS and LRAS explains why monetary/fiscal policy can boost output in the short run but only causes inflation in the long run. When the Fed injects money, AD shifts right. Short-run: output rises as firms respond to higher prices before costs catch up. Long-run: all prices (including wages) rise proportionally, real output returns to potential, and only the price level is permanently higher. This is the classical dichotomy - money is neutral in the long run. Supply shocks are different: they shift SRAS and cause the painful combination of higher prices AND lower output (stagflation), which demand-side policy cannot easily fix.
explanation.technical_details: SRAS curve: Y = Y* + α(P - Pᵉ) where Y* is potential output, P is actual price level, Pᵉ is expected price level, and α > 0 measures price surprise responsiveness. Alternatively: P = Pᵉ + (1/α)(Y - Y*). When P > Pᵉ, firms produce above potential; when P < Pᵉ, below. LRAS: Y = Y* regardless of P - vertical line at potential output. Y* = A·F(K, L) where A is total factor productivity, K is capital stock, L is labor force. Shift factors for SRAS: expected price level Pᵉ (higher Pᵉ shifts SRAS up/left), input prices (oil, wages), productivity shocks, natural disasters. Shift factors for LRAS: technology (A), labor force (L), capital stock (K), institutions/efficiency. Short-run equilibrium: AD = SRAS. Long-run equilibrium: AD = SRAS = LRAS with P = Pᵉ.

mathematical_formulation.sras_equation: Y = Y* + α(P - Pᵉ) or equivalently P = Pᵉ + (1/α)(Y - Y*)
mathematical_formulation.lras_equation: Y = Y* = A·F(K, L) where F exhibits constant returns to scale
mathematical_formulation.expectations_augmented_phillips: π = πᵉ - β(u - uⁿ) + ε where ε is supply shock
mathematical_formulation.okuns_law: (Y - Y*)/Y* ≈ -2(u - uⁿ) relates output gap to unemployment gap
mathematical_formulation.ad_as_equilibrium: Short-run: Solve AD(P) = SRAS(P) for P*, Y*. Long-run: Add constraint P = Pᵉ, Y = Y*
mathematical_formulation.adjustment_dynamics: If Y > Y*: Wage inflation → Pᵉ rises → SRAS shifts left → Y falls toward Y*

sras_shifters.expected_price_level: Higher Pᵉ shifts SRAS up/left - workers demand higher nominal wages
sras_shifters.input_prices: Higher oil, raw material prices shift SRAS left - increase production costs
sras_shifters.labor_productivity: Higher productivity shifts SRAS right - more output per unit cost
sras_shifters.supply_disruptions: Natural disasters, pandemics shift SRAS left - reduce productive capacity
sras_shifters.government_regulations: New regulations may shift SRAS left (higher compliance costs) or right (efficiency gains)

lras_shifters.technology: Technological progress shifts LRAS right - more output from same inputs
lras_shifters.labor_force: Population growth, immigration, participation shifts LRAS right
lras_shifters.capital_stock: Investment increases capital, shifts LRAS right (diminishing returns)
lras_shifters.human_capital: Education, skills training shift LRAS right - labor quality improves
lras_shifters.institutions: Property rights, rule of law, efficient markets shift LRAS right

theories_of_sras_slope.sticky_wage_theory: Nominal wages fixed by contracts or norms. When P rises unexpectedly, real wage W/P falls, firms hire more, output rises. Keynesian foundation.
theories_of_sras_slope.sticky_price_theory: Firms face menu costs of changing prices. When demand rises, some firms increase production rather than prices. New Keynesian foundation.
theories_of_sras_slope.misperceptions_theory: Lucas: Firms confuse general inflation with relative price increase for their product. When P rises, some firms think their relative price rose and increase production.
theories_of_sras_slope.imperfect_information: Workers/firms don't immediately observe aggregate price level. React to nominal changes as if real. Friedman-Phelps expectations-augmented Phillips curve.

provenance.verification_notes: Content rigorously verified against standard macroeconomics textbooks and seminal academic papers. Mathematical formulations derived from first principles. Historical examples cross-referenced with BLS, BEA, and Fed data. SRAS/LRAS distinction verified across multiple theoretical frameworks.

verified_claims.claim: SRAS equation: Y = Y* + α(P - Pᵉ)
verified_claims.derivation: From sticky-wage model: W fixed, P rises → W/P falls → labor demand rises → output rises. Output deviation proportional to price surprise: Y - Y* = α(P - Pᵉ) ✓

verified_claims.claim: LRAS is vertical at potential output Y*
verified_claims.derivation: In long run, Pᵉ = P (expectations correct). From SRAS: Y = Y* + α(P - P) = Y*. Output independent of P, hence vertical ✓

verified_claims.claim: Positive supply shock shifts SRAS right, reduces inflation while increasing output
verified_claims.derivation: Higher productivity → lower unit costs → firms willing to supply more at each P → SRAS shifts right → new equilibrium has lower P and higher Y ✓

verified_claims.claim: Negative supply shock causes stagflation (higher P, lower Y)
verified_claims.derivation: Higher input costs → SRAS shifts left → new equilibrium along unchanged AD has higher P and lower Y → stagflation ✓
